friends.desc: The cozy New York coffeehouse where the six friends spend a huge part of their lives.
Phoebe’s hilariously offbeat song about a very unfortunate feline.
Phoebe’s go-to alias used in all kinds of chaotic situations.
Joey’s famous flirtatious catchphrase used on just about everyone.
Ross’s shouted instruction while trying to move a couch up a staircase.
Ross’s defensive line about his relationship status with Rachel.
The two-part episode where Chandler’s proposal plan slowly falls apart.
The organized, competitive chef who loves hosting game nights and dinners.
She starts as a runaway bride and ends up working in fashion.
The king of sarcasm who works in statistical analysis and data reconfiguration.
The manager of Central Perk with an unrequited love for Rachel.
Chandler's on-again, off-again girlfriend with a distinctive voice and laugh.
The neighbor across the street who the friends often watch from Monica's apartment.
One of the many quirky names Phoebe considered for her band.
Joey's most famous role as a neurosurgeon on 'Days of Our Lives'.
The absurd name Phoebe legally changes hers to, much to Mike's dismay.
Monica's older brother, a paleontologist with a history of failed marriages.
The lovable, food-obsessed actor who is fiercely loyal to his friends.
The eccentric masseuse and self-taught musician with a mysterious past.
Ross's prized post-Thanksgiving sandwich with a gravy-soaked bread slice in the middle.
Ross's alternative to Santa Claus to teach his son Ben about Hanukkah.
The name on Chandler's TV Guide, which becomes a running joke.
Rachel's infamous Thanksgiving dessert that was half English trifle and half shepherd's pie.
The quiz game that results in Monica and Rachel losing their apartment to Chandler and Joey.
Phoebe's eccentric half-brother for whom she acts as a surrogate.
The daughter of Ross Geller and Rachel Green, born in season eight.
A pianist who ends up marrying Phoebe after Joey sets them up on a blind date.
An ophthalmologist and friend of Monica's parents, whom she dates for a significant time.
Rachel's young, attractive assistant whom she hires over a more qualified woman.
The source of many competitive games between Chandler and Joey.

tbbt.desc: The lullaby Sheldon wants when he is sick, originally sung by his mom.
Sheldon’s word for signaling that he just made a joke or pulled a prank.
A brilliant yet socially awkward physicist with strict routines and rules.
The aspiring actress who lives across the hall and grounds the group socially.
The detailed contract that governs Sheldon and Leonard’s living situation.
The sitcom following a group of scientists and their lives in Pasadena.
Initially unable to talk to women unless he has had a drink.
The aerospace engineer known for his flashy wardrobe and belt buckles.
The restaurant where Penny works as a waitress early in the series.
The specific spot on the couch that is optimal for comfort and viewing.
Sheldon's long-suffering roommate and the 'Kirk' of the group.
Sheldon's counterpart and eventual wife, introduced via an online dating site.
A microbiologist with a sweet but fierce personality, who marries Howard.
The perpetually down-on-his-luck owner of the comic book store the guys frequent.
Sheldon's educational web series about vexillology, often featuring Amy.
An expanded version of the classic game invented by Sam Kass and introduced by Sheldon.
The California Institute of Technology, where the main characters work.
The city in California where the series is set.
A quantum mechanics thought experiment often referenced by Sheldon to explain uncertainty.
Sheldon's Halloween costume, representing the change in frequency of a wave in relation to an observer.
The guys often dress up as members of this superhero team for costume parties.
A dermatologist with a fascination for the macabre who dates Raj.
The actor from 'Star Trek: The Next Generation' who plays a fictionalized, evil version of himself.
A theoretical framework in which the point-like particles of particle physics are replaced by one-dimensional objects called strings.
Raj's inability to speak to women, which he overcomes later in the series.

tbbt.word: THE WOLOWITZ ZERO-GRAVITY WASTE DISPOSAL SYSTEM
tbbt.desc: Howard's engineering project for the International Space Station that famously malfunctioned.
Sheldon is an avid train enthusiast and enjoys playing with train simulators.
Howard and Bernadette's first child, named after the famous comet.
The prestigious award in physics that Sheldon and Amy win for their work on super-asymmetry.
The name Sheldon gives to one of the many cats he adopts during a brief breakup with Amy.

science.desc: The fundamental force that attracts objects with mass toward one another.
Plants convert light, water and carbon dioxide into energy.
The gradual development of species driven by natural selection.
A region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that not even light can escape.
The molecule that carries the genetic instructions for life.
The basic unit of matter made of protons, neutrons and electrons.
Leading theory describing the universe’s expansion from a hot dense state.
A nerve cell that transmits information via electrical and chemical signals.
A substance that trains the immune system to recognize and fight pathogens.
Weird, discrete behavior of matter and energy at tiny scales.
The theory that Earth's outer shell is divided into several plates that glide over the mantle.
The change in frequency of a wave in relation to an observer who is moving relative to the wave source.
The theory developed by Albert Einstein, encompassing both special and general relativity, concerning space, time, and gravity.
A tabular arrangement of the chemical elements, ordered by their atomic number.
A technology that can be used to edit genes and has wide-ranging applications in medicine and biology.
An elementary particle in the Standard Model of particle physics, produced by the quantum excitation of the Higgs field.
An organelle found in large numbers in most cells, in which the biochemical processes of respiration and energy production occur.
A set of physical properties observed in certain materials where electrical resistance vanishes and magnetic flux fields are expelled from the material.
A scientific concept as well as a measurable physical property that is most commonly associated with a state of disorder, randomness, or uncertainty.
A nuclear reaction in which the nucleus of an atom splits into smaller parts (lighter nuclei).
A reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei are combined to form one or more different atomic nuclei and subatomic particles.
A type of antimicrobial substance active against bacteria.
A community of living organisms in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment, interacting as a system.
All the genetic information of an organism, consisting of nucleotide sequences of DNA.
An extremely luminous active galactic nucleus, in which a supermassive black hole is surrounded by a gaseous accretion disk.
A highly magnetized rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation out of its magnetic poles.
A piece of equipment that puts an object in rotation around a fixed axis, applying a potent force perpendicular to the axis of spin.
A substance or material consisting of very large molecules, or macromolecules, composed of many repeating subunits.
The spontaneous net movement of solvent molecules through a selectively permeable membrane into a region of higher solute concentration.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.

history.desc: Monumental tombs built for Egyptian pharaohs, still standing after millennia.
Artifact that helped scholars read ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs.
Factories, steam engines and mass production transformed society.
Vast network of routes connecting Asia, Europe and Africa.
Cultural rebirth in Europe marked by advances in art and science.
Made books cheaper and knowledge easier to spread.
Series of fortifications built to protect against invasions.
Profitable trade in spices that drove exploration and sea voyages.
Era when European sailors mapped new sea routes and continents.
Historical region often called the cradle of civilization.
A well-preserved Babylonian code of law of ancient Mesopotamia, dating back to about 1754 BC.
A Roman general and statesman who played a critical role in the events that led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire.
A series of religious wars between Christians and Muslims started primarily to secure control of holy sites.
A charter of rights agreed to by King John of England in 1215, which limited the power of the monarch.
A bubonic plague pandemic occurring in Afro-Eurasia from 1346 to 1353, it is the most fatal pandemic recorded in human history.
Scandinavian seafaring pirates and traders who raided and settled in many parts of northwestern Europe in the 8th–11th centuries.
A period of geopolitical tension between the United States and the Soviet Union and their respective allies, from 1947 to 1991.
The spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on July 20, 1969.
A guarded concrete barrier that physically and ideologically divided Berlin from 1961 to 1989.
A major movement within Western Christianity in 16th-century Europe that posed a religious and political challenge to the Catholic Church.
The founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire, which became the largest contiguous empire in history after his death.
An empire that controlled much of Southeast Europe, Western Asia, and Northern Africa between the 14th and early 20th centuries.
A Mesoamerican culture that flourished in central Mexico in the post-classic period from 1300 to 1521.
The largest empire in pre-Columbian America, centered in what is now Peru, from 1438 to 1533.
A Habsburg Spanish fleet of 130 ships that sailed from Lisbon in 1588 with the purpose of escorting an army to invade England.
A period of far-reaching social and political upheaval in France and its colonies beginning in 1789.
A French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led several successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars.
A global war originating in Europe that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918.
The genocide of European Jews during World War II. Between 1941 and 1945, Nazi Germany and its collaborators systematically murdered some six million Jews.
An artificial sea-level waterway in Egypt, connecting the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea through the Isthmus of Suez.

movies.desc: Glowing weapon used by space knights in a famous sci-fi saga.
A school of wizardry attended by a well-known young wizard.
A theme park filled with cloned dinosaurs that goes wrong.
A sci-fi thriller about stealing and planting ideas in shared dreams.
A hacker discovers the world he knows is a simulated reality.
A high-tech suit that launched a cinematic universe.
Saga centered on a powerful mafia family.
Romance set aboard an ill-fated luxury ship.
Teenager travels through time in a modified DeLorean.
Crime-ridden city protected by a masked vigilante.
A paraplegic marine dispatched to the moon Pandora on a unique mission becomes torn between following orders and protecting the world he feels is his home.
The lives of two mob hitmen, a boxer, a gangster and his wife, and a pair of diner bandits intertwine in four tales of violence and redemption.

movies.hint: Life is like a box of chocolates
movies.desc: The presidencies of Kennedy and Johnson, the Vietnam War, the Watergate scandal and other historical events unfold from the perspective of an Alabama man with an IQ of 75.
Two imprisoned men bond over a number of years, finding solace and eventual redemption through acts of common decency.
When the menace known as the Joker wreaks havoc and chaos on the people of Gotham, Batman must accept one of the greatest psychological and physical tests of his ability to fight injustice.
Luke Skywalker joins forces with a Jedi Knight, a cocky pilot, a Wookiee and two droids to save the galaxy from the Empire's world-destroying battle station.

movies.hint: One Ring to rule them all
movies.desc: A meek Hobbit from the Shire and eight companions set out on a journey to destroy the powerful One Ring and save Middle-earth from the Dark Lord Sauron.
A troubled child summons the courage to help a friendly alien escape Earth and return to his home planet.
Dorothy Gale is swept away from a farm in Kansas to a magical land of Oz in a tornado and embarks on a quest with her new friends to see the Wizard who can help her return home.
A manipulative woman and a roguish man conduct a turbulent romance during the American Civil War and Reconstruction periods.
A cynical American expatriate struggles to decide whether or not he should help his former lover and her fugitive husband escape French Morocco.
A Phoenix secretary embezzles $40,000 from her employer's client, goes on the run, and checks into a remote motel run by a young man under the domination of his mother.

movies.hint: You're gonna need a bigger boat
movies.desc: A local sheriff, a marine biologist, and an old seafarer hunt a man-eating great white shark that is terrorizing a summer resort town.
A human soldier is sent from 2029 to 1984 to stop an almost indestructible cyborg killing machine, sent from the same year, which has been programmed to execute a young woman.

movies.hint: In space no one can hear you scream
movies.desc: After a space merchant vessel perceives an unknown transmission as a distress call, one of the crew is attacked by a mysterious life form and they soon realize that its life cycle has merely begun.
A blade runner must pursue and terminate four replicants who stole a ship in space, and have returned to Earth to find their creator.
An insomniac office worker looking for a way to change his life crosses paths with a devil-may-care soap maker and they form an underground fight club that evolves into something much, much more.
The story of Henry Hill and his life in the mob, covering his relationship with his wife Karen Hill and his mob partners Jimmy Conway and Tommy DeVito.
A young F.B.I. cadet must receive the help of an incarcerated and manipulative cannibal killer to help catch another serial killer, a madman who skins his victims.
Greed and class discrimination threaten the newly formed symbiotic relationship between the wealthy Park family and the destitute Kim clan.

geo.desc: Tallest mountain above sea level on Earth.
Carries the most water of any river.
Largest hot desert in the world.
World’s largest coral reef system.
City that spans Europe and Asia.
Historically considered the longest river in the world, flowing northward through northeastern Africa.
A waterfall on the Zambezi River in southern Africa, providing a habitat for several unique species of plants and animals.
A steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River in Arizona, United States.
Japan's tallest peak, an active volcano that has become a symbol of the country.
A waterfall in Venezuela. It is the world's tallest uninterrupted waterfall.
A desert valley in Eastern California, in the northern Mojave Desert, bordering the Great Basin Desert.
An archipelago of volcanic islands around the equator in the Pacific Ocean, belonging to Ecuador.
A geographical region in Africa, spanning northern Tanzania. It is famous for its annual migration of over 1.5 million white-bearded wildebeest.
An Incan citadel set high in the Andes Mountains in Peru, above the Urubamba River valley.
A city in northeastern Italy and the capital of the Veneto region, built on more than 100 small islands in a lagoon in the Adriatic Sea.
Earth's southernmost continent. It contains the geographic South Pole and is situated in the Antarctic region of the Southern Hemisphere.
A large desert or brushland region in East Asia, covering parts of Northern and Northeastern China and of Southern Mongolia.
A mountain of the Alps, straddling the main watershed and border between Switzerland and Italy.
A salt lake bordered by Jordan to the east and Israel and the West Bank to the west. Its surface and shores are 430.5 metres below sea level, Earth's lowest elevation on land.
An artificial 82 km waterway in Panama that connects the Atlantic Ocean with the Pacific Ocean.
A mountain range in Asia separating the plains of the Indian subcontinent from the Tibetan Plateau.
A city located in the central part of the island of Honshu, Japan. It's famous for its classical Buddhist temples, as well as gardens, imperial palaces, Shinto shrines and traditional wooden houses.
A city and emirate in the United Arab Emirates known for luxury shopping, ultramodern architecture and a lively nightlife scene.
A huge seaside city in Brazil, famed for its Copacabana and Ipanema beaches, Christ the Redeemer statue, and for its sprawling favelas.
Russia’s cosmopolitan capital, home to the Kremlin, Red Square, and St. Basil's Cathedral.
The capital of New South Wales and one of Australia's largest cities, best known for its harbourfront Sydney Opera House.
Egypt’s sprawling capital, set on the Nile River. At its heart is Tahrir Square and the vast Egyptian Museum.
The densely populated, high-altitude capital of Mexico. It's known for its Templo Mayor (a 13th-century Aztec temple), the baroque Catedral Metropolitana de México and the Palacio Nacional.
Germany's capital, dating to the 13th century. Reminders of the city's turbulent 20th-century history include its Holocaust Memorial and the Berlin Wall's graffitied remains.
Italy’s capital, a sprawling, cosmopolitan city with nearly 3,000 years of globally influential art, architecture and culture on display.

literature.desc: Famed sleuth of Baker Street.
A peaceful village of hobbits.
Magical land entered through a wardrobe.
Idealistic knight who tilts at windmills.
Mysterious millionaire longing for Daisy.
A young wizard who discovers his magical heritage on his eleventh birthday when he receives a letter of acceptance to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
A romantic novel of manners written by Jane Austen in 1813. The novel follows the character development of Elizabeth Bennet.
A novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It was immediately successful, winning the Pulitzer Prize, and has become a classic of modern American literature.
A dystopian social science fiction novel by English novelist George Orwell. It was published in 1949.
A 1925 novel by American writer F. Scott Fitzgerald. Set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, the novel depicts narrator Nick Carraway's interactions with mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby.
The 1851 novel by Herman Melville. The story tells the adventures of wandering sailor Ishmael, and his voyage on the whaleship Pequod, commanded by Captain Ahab.
A novel by the Russian author Leo Tolstoy, first published in 1869. The work is epic in scale and is regarded as one of the most important works of world literature.
A novel by J. D. Salinger, partially published in serial form in 1945–1946 and as a novel in 1951.
A novel written by English author Mary Shelley that tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a sapient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment.

An 1865 novel by English author Lewis Carroll. It tells of a young girl named Alice, who falls through a rabbit hole into a subterranean fantasy world populated by peculiar, anthropomorphic creatures.
An 1897 Gothic horror novel by Irish author Bram Stoker. It introduced the character of Count Dracula and established many conventions of subsequent vampire fantasy.
A novel by English writer Charlotte Brontë, published under the pen name 'Currer Bell', on 16 October 1847.
One of two major ancient Greek epic poems attributed to Homer. It is one of the oldest extant works of literature still read by contemporary audiences.
A tragedy written by William Shakespeare early in his career about two young Italian star-crossed lovers whose deaths ultimately reconcile their feuding families.

literature.hint: To be or not to be
literature.desc: A tragedy written by William Shakespeare sometime between 1599 and 1601. It is Shakespeare's longest play.
A novel by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky. It was first published in the literary journal The Russian Messenger in twelve monthly installments during 1866.
A dystopian novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932.
A children's fantasy novel by English author J. R. R. Tolkien. It was published on 21 September 1937 to wide critical acclaim.
A 1953 dystopian novel by American writer Ray Bradbury. It presents a future American society where books are outlawed and 'firemen' burn any that are found.
A French historical novel by Victor Hugo, first published in 1862, that is considered one of the greatest novels of the 19th century.
A Spanish novel by Miguel de Cervantes. Published in two parts, in 1605 and 1615, it is the founding work of Western literature.
A philosophical novel by Oscar Wilde, first published complete in the July 1890 issue of Lippincott's Monthly Magazine.
A 1726 prose satire by the Irish writer and clergyman Jonathan Swift, satirising both human nature and the 'travellers' tales' literary subgenre.
A novella by Polish-English novelist Joseph Conrad about a narrated voyage up the Congo River into the Congo Free State in the Heart of Africa.

literature.hint: Best of times, worst of times
literature.desc: An 1859 historical novel by Charles Dickens, set in London and Paris before and during the French Revolution.

animals.desc: A large cat known for its incredible speed, reaching up to 75 mph in short bursts.
The largest animal on Earth, its heart is the size of a small car.
Known for its extremely long neck and distinctive coat pattern.
A bird that lives in the Southern Hemisphere and is highly adapted for life in the water.
Famous for carrying its young in a pouch and moving by hopping.
A large mammal with a trunk, large ears, and tusks, known for its intelligence and memory.
A large cat that traditionally lives in prides, with males having a distinctive mane.
The largest cat species, most recognizable for their dark vertical stripes on orange-brown fur.
A hypercarnivorous bear whose native range lies largely within the Arctic Circle.
A ground-dwelling, predominantly herbivorous ape that inhabits the forests of central Sub-Saharan Africa.
A highly intelligent marine mammal known for its playful behavior and use of echolocation.
A soft-bodied, eight-limbed mollusc of the order Octopoda, known for its intelligence and ability to change color.
A large predatory semiaquatic reptile with a long snout, powerful jaws, and a body covered in bony plates.
A bear native to south-central China, characterized by its black-and-white coat and diet of bamboo.
An arboreal herbivorous marsupial native to Australia, often mistakenly called a bear.
An African wild horse with black-and-white stripes and a social nature.
A large, herbivorous mammal identified by its characteristic horned snouts.
A large, semi-aquatic mammal native to sub-Saharan Africa, known for its territorial nature.
A toothed whale belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, it is the largest member of the dolphin family.
A species of large mackerel shark which can be found in the coastal surface waters of all the major oceans.
A bird of prey found in North America, known for its white head and tail feathers.
A species of lizard found in the Indonesian islands of Komodo, Rinca, Flores, and Gili Motang.
A slow-moving, tree-dwelling mammal native to the tropical rainforests of Central and South America.
A small carnivoran belonging to the mongoose family, known for its upright posture and social colonies.
A New World placental mammal with a leathery armor shell.
A semiaquatic, egg-laying mammal endemic to eastern Australia, with a bill like a duck.
A paedomorphic salamander related to the tiger salamander, known for its ability to regenerate limbs.
A giant cavy rodent native to South America, known for its calm and social demeanor.
A small crepuscular fox native to the Sahara Desert, recognizable by its unusually large ears.
A large cat native to the mountain ranges of Central and South Asia, known for its elusive nature.

food.desc: A dish of Italian origin consisting of a usually round, flat base of leavened wheat-based dough topped with tomatoes, cheese, and various other ingredients.
A Japanese dish of prepared vinegared rice, usually with some sugar and salt, accompanying a variety of ingredients, such as seafood, often raw, and vegetables.
A traditional Mexican dish consisting of a small hand-sized corn or wheat tortilla topped with a filling.
A buttery, flaky, viennoiserie pastry of Austrian origin, but mostly associated with France.
A Spanish rice dish originally from Valencia. It is one of the best-known dishes in Spanish cuisine.
A sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun.
A Japanese noodle soup dish. It consists of Chinese-style wheat noodles served in a meat or fish-based broth, often flavored with soy sauce or miso.
A variety of dishes originating in the Indian subcontinent that use a complex combination of spices or herbs, usually including ground turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger, and fresh or dried chilies.
A type of food typically made from an unleavened dough of wheat flour mixed with water or eggs, and formed into sheets or various shapes.
A traditional Korean side dish of salted and fermented vegetables, such as napa cabbage and Korean radish.
A deep-fried ball or patty made from ground chickpeas, fava beans, or both.
A Middle Eastern dip, spread, or savory dish made from cooked, mashed chickpeas blended with tahini, lemon juice, and garlic.
A South American seafood dish that originated in Peru, typically made from fresh raw fish cured in fresh citrus juices, most commonly lemon or lime.
A Greek dish made from meat cooked on a vertical rotisserie, traditionally pork, or chicken, and served wrapped in a flatbread such as pita.
A Vietnamese soup consisting of broth, rice noodles, herbs, and meat, primarily made with either beef or chicken.
A large range of small dishes that Cantonese people traditionally enjoy in restaurants for breakfast and lunch.

A sour soup common in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia. In English, the word 'borscht' is most often associated with the soup's variant of Ukrainian origin, made with beetroots as one of the main ingredients.
A hot dish consisting of fried fish in batter, served with chips. The dish originated in England.
A dish of french fries and cheese curds topped with a brown gravy. It emerged in Quebec, Canada, in the late 1950s.
A stew of beans with beef and pork. It is a typical dish in Portugal and former Portuguese colonies, such as Brazil, Angola, and Macau.
An eggplant- or potato-based dish, often including ground meat, which is common in the Balkans and the Middle East.
A dish of cooked land snails, usually served as an appetizer in France and in French restaurants.
Finely cut raw cabbage that has been fermented by various lactic acid bacteria.
An antipasto from Italy consisting of grilled bread rubbed with garlic and topped with olive oil and salt.
A strip of fried dough, sometimes filled, popular in Spain, Portugal, and Latin America.
The Italian word for ice cream, it is made with a base of milk, cream, and sugar, and flavored with fruit and nut purees and other flavorings.
A sweet meringue-based confection made with egg white, icing sugar, granulated sugar, almond powder or ground almond, and food colouring.
A coffee-flavoured Italian dessert. It is made of ladyfingers dipped in coffee, layered with a whipped mixture of eggs, sugar, and mascarpone cheese, flavoured with cocoa.
A layered pastry dessert made of filo pastry, filled with chopped nuts, and sweetened with syrup or honey.
An Italian dessert of sweetened cream thickened with gelatin and molded. The cream may be aromatized with coffee, vanilla, or other flavorings.

tech.desc: The global system of interconnected computer networks that uses the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP) to communicate between networks and devices.
A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer.
A system of recording information in a way that makes it difficult or impossible to change, hack, or cheat the system.
The theory and development of computer systems able to perform tasks that normally require human intelligence.
A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
A type of computation that harnesses the collective properties of quantum states, such as superposition, interference, and entanglement, to perform calculations.
An interactive experience of a real-world environment where the objects that reside in the real world are enhanced by computer-generated perceptual information.
The study of computer algorithms that can improve automatically through experience and by the use of data.

A system of interrelated computing devices, mechanical and digital machines, objects, animals or people that are provided with unique identifiers and the ability to transfer data over a network without requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction.
The practice of defending computers, servers, mobile devices, electronic systems, networks, and data from malicious attacks.
The on-demand availability of computer system resources, especially data storage and computing power, without direct active management by the user.

A field that treats ways to analyze, systematically extract information from, or otherwise deal with data sets that are too large or complex to be dealt with by traditional data-processing application software.
An unmanned aircraft. Drones are more formally known as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) or unmanned aircraft systems (UASes).
A process of making three dimensional solid objects from a digital file.
Body measurements and calculations related to human characteristics. Biometrics authentication is used in computer science as a form of identification and access control.

tech.hint: Manipulating matter on an atomic scale
tech.desc: The manipulation of matter on an atomic, molecular, and supramolecular scale.
A group of technologies that give scientists the ability to change an organism's DNA.
An interdisciplinary field that integrates computer science and engineering. Robotics involves the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.
A category of electronic devices that can be worn as accessories, embedded in clothing, implanted in the user's body, or even tattooed on the skin.
A distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the sources of data.
The fifth-generation technology standard for broadband cellular networks, which cellular phone companies began deploying worldwide in 2019.
A computer program or a transaction protocol which is intended to automatically execute, control or document legally relevant events and actions according to the terms of a contract or an agreement.
A series of algorithms that endeavors to recognize underlying relationships in a set of data through a process that mimics the way the human brain operates.
A connection between computers or between computer programs. It is a type of software interface, offering a service to other pieces of software.
A form of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons and audio indicator such as primary notation, instead of text-based user interfaces.
A specific class of computer software that provides the low-level control for a device's specific hardware.

A type of computer software in which source code is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to use, study, change, and distribute the software to anyone and for any purpose.
Any form of interaction involving touch. Haptic technology can create an experience of touch by applying forces, vibrations, or motions to the user.
Synthetic media in which a person in an existing image or video is replaced with someone else's likeness.

A network of 3D virtual worlds focused on social connection. In futurism and science fiction, it is often described as a hypothetical iteration of the Internet as a single, universal virtual world that is facilitated by the use of virtual and augmented reality headsets.

mythology.desc: The god of the sky and thunder in ancient Greek religion, who rules as king of the gods of Mount Olympus.
A prominent Norse god associated with thunder, lightning, storms, oak trees, strength, the protection of mankind, and also hallowing and fertility.
The Greek name of the god of death, mummification, embalming, the afterlife, cemeteries, tombs, and the Underworld, in ancient Egyptian religion.

A widely revered god in Germanic mythology. In Norse mythology, from which most surviving information about the god stems, he is associated with wisdom, healing, death, royalty, the gallows, knowledge, war, battle, victory, sorcery, poetry, frenzy, and the runic alphabet.
A monster, a Gorgon, generally described as a winged human female with living venomous snakes in place of hair.
The ancient Greek chthonic god of the underworld, which eventually took his name.
A god in Norse mythology. Loki is in some sources the son of Fárbauti and Laufey, and the brother of Helblindi and Býleistr.
The ancient Egyptian deity of the sun. By the Fifth Dynasty, in the 25th and 24th centuries BC, he had become one of the most important gods in ancient Egyptian religion.
A divine hero in Greek mythology, the son of Zeus and Alcmene, and the foster son of Amphitryon.
A hero of the Trojan War, the greatest of all the Greek warriors, and is the central character of Homer's Iliad.
A mythical creature portrayed in Classical times with the head and tail of a bull and the body of a man.
A creature from Greek mythology with the upper body of a human and the lower body and legs of a horse.
A member of a primordial race of giants, each with a single eye in the center of his forehead.
A long-lived bird that cyclically regenerates or is otherwise born again.
One of a host of female figures who choose those who may die in battle and those who may live.
In Norse mythology, a series of future events, including a great battle, foretold to ultimately result in the death of a number of major figures.
The legendary sword of King Arthur, sometimes attributed with magical powers or associated with the rightful sovereignty of Great Britain.
A castle and court associated with the legendary King Arthur.
A major hero in ancient Mesopotamian mythology and the protagonist of the Epic of Gilgamesh, an epic poem written in Akkadian during the late 2nd millennium BC.
A female spirit in Irish folklore who heralds the death of a family member, usually by wailing, shrieking, or keening.
A type of fairy in Irish folklore, usually depicted as a little bearded man, wearing a coat and hat, who partakes in mischief.
A legendary sea monster of giant size that is said to dwell off the coasts of Norway and Greenland.
A mythical winged divine horse, and one of the most recognized creatures in Greek mythology.
Dangerous creatures, who lured nearby sailors with their enchanting music and singing voices to shipwreck on the rocky coast of their island.
An immense and central sacred tree in Norse cosmology. Around it exists all else, including the Nine Worlds.

music.desc: An English rock band formed in Liverpool in 1960, widely regarded as the most influential band of all time.
A prolific and influential composer of the Classical period. Born in Salzburg, in the Holy Roman Empire, he showed prodigious ability from his earliest childhood.

An electronic musical instrument that generates audio signals. Synthesizers typically create sounds by generating waveforms, through methods including subtractive synthesis, additive synthesis and frequency modulation synthesis.
A music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans, Louisiana, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with its roots in blues and ragtime.

A fretted musical instrument that typically has six strings. It is held flat against the player's body and played by strumming or plucking the strings with the dominant hand, while simultaneously pressing selected strings against frets with the fingers of the opposite hand.
A British rock band formed in London in 1970. Their classic line-up was Freddie Mercury, Brian May, Roger Taylor and John Deacon.

music.hint: The King of Rock and Roll
music.desc: An American singer and actor. Regarded as one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century.
An American singer, songwriter, and dancer. He is regarded as one of the most significant cultural figures of the 20th century.
An American singer-songwriter, author and visual artist. Widely regarded as one of the greatest songwriters of all time.

An American rock guitarist, singer, and songwriter. Although his mainstream career spanned only four years, he is widely regarded as one of the most influential electric guitarists in the history of popular music.
A culture and art movement that was created by African Americans, Latino Americans and Caribbean Americans in the Bronx, New York City.
A form of theatre in which music has a leading role and the parts are taken by singers.
A family of woodwind instruments usually made of brass and played with a single-reed mouthpiece.
A high-pitched wooden string instrument in the violin family. It is the smallest and thus highest-pitched instrument in the family in regular use.
A collection of drums, cymbals and other percussion instruments, which are set up on stands to be played by a single player.
A music festival held August 15–18, 1969, on a dairy farm in Bethel, New York. Billed as 'an Aquarian Exposition: 3 Days of Peace & Music'.
An award presented by the Recording Academy to recognize 'outstanding' achievements in the music industry.
An English rock band formed in London in 1962. A diverging act to the popular pop rock of the early-1960s, the Rolling Stones pioneered the gritty, heavier-driven sound that came to define hard rock.
An American rock band formed in Aberdeen, Washington, in 1987. Founded by lead singer and guitarist Kurt Cobain and bassist Krist Novoselic.
A French electronic music duo formed in 1993 in Paris by Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo and Thomas Bangalter.
An American singer, songwriter, and actress. Born and raised in Houston, Texas, Beyoncé performed in various singing and dancing competitions as a child.
An American singer-songwriter. Her narrative songwriting, which often centers around her personal life, has received widespread critical praise and media coverage.
An English singer and songwriter. After graduating from the BRIT School in 2006, Adele signed a record deal with XL Recordings.
An English singer, songwriter, musician, record producer, actor, and businessman. He has sold more than 150 million records worldwide, making him one of the world's best-selling music artists.
A large instrumental ensemble typical of classical music, which combines instruments from different families.
Any harmonic set of pitches consisting of multiple notes that are heard as if sounding simultaneously.
A linear sequence of musical notes that the listener perceives as a single entity.
The pattern of sound, silence, and emphasis in a song.
A set of words that make up a song, usually consisting of verses and choruses.

art.desc: A half-length portrait painting by Italian artist Leonardo da Vinci. Considered an archetypal masterpiece of the Italian Renaissance, it has been described as 'the best known, the most visited, the most written about, the most sung about, the most parodied work of art in the world'.

An oil-on-canvas painting by the Dutch Post-Impressionist painter Vincent van Gogh. Painted in June 1889, it depicts the view from the east-facing window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, just before sunrise, with the addition of an imaginary village.

A 19th-century art movement characterized by relatively small, thin, yet visible brush strokes, open composition, emphasis on accurate depiction of light in its changing qualities (often accentuating the effects of the passage of time), ordinary subject matter, unusual visual angles, and inclusion of movement as a crucial element of human perception and experience.

The branch of the visual arts that operates in three dimensions. It is one of the plastic arts. Durable sculptural processes originally used carving (the removal of material) and modelling (the addition of material, as clay), in stone, metal, ceramics, wood and other materials.

A Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist and theatre designer who spent most of his adult life in France. Regarded as one of the most influential artists of the 20th century, he is known for co-founding the Cubist movement.
A late 15th-century mural painting by Italian artist Leonardo da Vinci housed by the refectory of the Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan, Italy.
The popular name given to a composition created by Norwegian Expressionist artist Edvard Munch in 1893.
A large 1937 oil painting on canvas by Spanish artist Pablo Picasso. It is one of his best known works, regarded by many art critics as the most moving and powerful anti-war painting in history.
A painting by the Italian artist Sandro Botticelli, probably made in the mid 1480s. It depicts the goddess Venus arriving at the shore after her birth, when she had emerged from the sea fully-grown.
A masterpiece of High Renaissance sculpture, created in marble between 1501 and 1504 by the Italian artist Michelangelo.
A cultural movement which developed in Europe in the aftermath of World War I and was largely influenced by Dada. The movement is best known for its visual artworks and writings.
An early-20th-century avant-garde art movement that revolutionized European painting and sculpture, and inspired related movements in music, literature and architecture.
A period in European history marking the transition from the Middle Ages to modernity and covering the 15th and 16th centuries.
A style of architecture, music, dance, painting, sculpture and other arts that flourished in Europe from the early 17th century until the 1740s.

An art movement that emerged in the United Kingdom and the United States during the mid- to late-1950s. The movement presented a challenge to traditions of fine art by including imagery from popular and mass culture.
A Mexican painter known for her many portraits, self-portraits, and works inspired by the nature and artifacts of Mexico.
A Spanish surrealist artist renowned for his technical skill, precise draftsmanship and the striking and bizarre images in his work.

A Dutch draughtsman, painter, and printmaker. An innovative and prolific master in three media, he is generally considered one of the greatest visual artists in the history of art and the most important in Dutch art history.
A French painter, a founder of French Impressionist painting and the most consistent and prolific practitioner of the movement's philosophy of expressing one's perceptions before nature.
An American modernist artist. She was known for her paintings of enlarged flowers, New York skyscrapers, and New Mexico landscapes.
A painting method in which the paints are made of pigments suspended in a water-based solution.
A piece of art or image made from the assembling of small pieces of colored glass, stone, or other materials.
A technique of mural painting executed upon freshly laid, or wet lime plaster.
A visual art related to writing. It is the design and execution of lettering with a pen, ink brush, or other writing instrument.
The Japanese art of folding paper into decorative shapes and figures.
Writing or drawings made on a wall or other surface, usually without permission and within public view.
The world's largest art museum and a historic monument in Paris, France.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art of New York City, colloquially 'the Met', is the largest art museum in the United States.
A modern art gallery located in London. It is Britain's national gallery of international modern art and forms part of the Tate group.
An art museum located in Midtown Manhattan, New York City, on 53rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

space.desc: An interstellar cloud of dust, hydrogen, helium and other ionized gases. Originally, the name was used to describe any diffused astronomical object, including galaxies beyond the Milky Way.

A powerful and luminous stellar explosion. This transient astronomical event occurs during the last evolutionary stages of a massive star or when a white dwarf is triggered into runaway nuclear fusion.
A gravitationally bound system of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter. The word is derived from the Greek galaxias, literally 'milky', a reference to the Milky Way.
A person trained by a human spaceflight program to command, pilot, or serve as a crew member of a spacecraft.
The galaxy that contains our Solar System, with the name describing the galaxy's appearance from Earth.
A barred spiral galaxy approximately 2.5 million light-years from Earth and the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way.
The cosmological model for the observable universe from the earliest known periods through its subsequent large-scale evolution.
A unit of astronomical distance equivalent to the distance that light travels in one year.
An area on the celestial sphere in which a group of visible stars forms a perceived outline or pattern, typically representing an animal, mythological person or creature, or an inanimate object.
A torus-shaped region in the Solar System, located roughly between the orbits of the planets Jupiter and Mars.
An icy, small Solar System body that, when passing close to the Sun, warms and begins to release gases, a process called outgassing.
An intense burst of radiation coming from the release of magnetic energy associated with sunspots.
A natural light display in the Earth's sky, predominantly seen in the high-latitude regions.
A modular space station in low Earth orbit. It is a multinational collaborative project involving five participating space agencies.
An American aerospace manufacturer, space transportation services and communications company founded by Elon Musk.
An American astronaut and aeronautical engineer, and the first person to walk on the Moon.
A motor vehicle that travels across the surface of the planet Mars upon arrival. Rovers have several advantages over stationary landers.
A planet outside the Solar System. The first confirmation of an exoplanet orbiting a main-sequence star was in 1995.
A form of matter thought to account for approximately 85% of the matter in the universe and about a quarter of its total mass–energy density.
A speculative structure linking disparate points in spacetime, and is based on a special solution of the Einstein field equations.
A prominent constellation located on the celestial equator and visible throughout the world. It is one of the most conspicuous and recognizable constellations in the night sky.
The fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System. It is a gas giant with a mass more than two and a half times that of all the other planets in the Solar System combined.
The sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest in the Solar System, after Jupiter. It is a gas giant with an average radius of about nine times that of Earth.
Two space probes, Voyager 1 and Voyager 2, launched by NASA in 1977. They were originally designed to study the outer planets, but have since continued their mission into interstellar space.

A distribution of matter (such as a cluster of galaxies) between a distant light source and an observer, that is capable of bending the light from the source as the light travels towards the observer.
A boundary beyond which events cannot affect an outside observer. It is most commonly associated with black holes.
Electromagnetic radiation which is a remnant from an early stage of the universe, also known as 'relic radiation'.
A highly magnetized rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation out of its magnetic poles.

gaming.desc: A sandbox video game developed by Mojang. The game was created by Markus 'Notch' Persson in the Java programming language. Following several early private testing versions, it was first made public in May 2009 before being fully released in November 2011.
A fictional character in the video game franchise of the same name, created by Japanese video game designer Shigeru Miyamoto for the Japanese company Nintendo.
A video game brand that consists of five home video game consoles, as well as a media center, an online service, a line of controllers, two handhelds and a phone, as well as multiple magazines.
A series of video games developed by Game Freak and published by Nintendo and The Pokémon Company under the Pokémon media franchise.
An online multiplayer social deduction game developed and published by American game studio Innersloth.
A massively multiplayer online role-playing game released in 2004 by Blizzard Entertainment.
A series of fantasy action role-playing games developed by CD Projekt Red. They are based on the book series of the same name by Polish writer Andrzej Sapkowski.
An action role-playing game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. It is the fifth main installment in The Elder Scrolls series.
A series of action-adventure games created by David Jones and Mike Dailly. Later titles were developed under the oversight of brothers Dan and Sam Houser, Leslie Benzies and Aaron Garbut.
A series of Western-themed action-adventure games created by Rockstar Games.
A first-person shooter video game franchise published by Activision. Starting out in 2003, it first focused on games set in World War II.
The title character and protagonist of the Sega video game series of the same name, as well as numerous spin-off comics, animations, and other media.
A maze arcade game developed and released by Namco in 1980.
A tile-matching video game created by Russian software engineer Alexey Pajitnov in 1984.
A social simulation video game series developed and published by Nintendo. The series was conceptualized and created by Katsuya Eguchi and Hisashi Nogami.
A Japanese science fantasy anthology media franchise created by Hironobu Sakaguchi, and developed and owned by Square Enix.
A media franchise consisting of action-adventure games, comic books, novels, theme park rides, and films, centring on the adventures of the fictional English archaeologist Lara Croft.
A series of multiplayer first-person shooter video games in which teams of terrorists battle to perpetrate an act of terror while counter-terrorists try to prevent it.
A 2009 multiplayer online battle arena video game developed and published by Riot Games.
A team-based multiplayer first-person shooter developed and published by Blizzard Entertainment.
An action role-playing video game developed and published by CD Projekt. The story takes place in Night City, an open world set in the Cyberpunk universe.
A military science fiction media franchise created by Bungie. The franchise is currently managed and developed by 343 Industries, and owned and published by Xbox Game Studios.
A Japanese competitive fighting video game franchise developed and published by Capcom.
An American media franchise centered on a series of fighting games originally developed by Midway Games in 1992.
A series of life simulation video games developed by Maxis and published by Electronic Arts.
A video game console developed by Nintendo and released worldwide in most regions on March 3, 2017.

A video gaming brand created and owned by Microsoft. The brand consists of five video game consoles, as well as applications (games), streaming services, an online service by the name of Xbox network, and the development arm by the name of Xbox Game Studios.
A video game digital distribution service by Valve. It was launched as a standalone software client in September 2003 as a way for Valve to provide automatic updates for their games.

nature.desc: A rupture in the crust of a planetary-mass object, such as Earth, that allows hot lava, volcanic ash, and gases to escape from a magma chamber below the surface.
An area of tall, mostly evergreen trees and a high amount of rainfall.
A type of biome where the tree growth is hindered by low temperatures and short growing seasons.
A deep, narrow valley with steep sides. The word comes from the Spanish cañón, which means 'tube' or 'pipe'.
A persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight. A glacier forms where the accumulation of snow exceeds its ablation over many years, often centuries.
The shaking of the surface of the Earth resulting from a sudden release of energy in the Earth's lithosphere that creates seismic waves.
A series of waves in a water body caused by the displacement of a large volume of water, generally in an ocean or a large lake.

A rapidly rotating storm system characterized by a low-pressure center, a closed low-level atmospheric circulation, strong winds, and a spiral arrangement of thunderstorms that produce heavy rain or squalls.
A violently rotating column of air that is in contact with both the surface of the Earth and a cumulonimbus cloud or, in rare cases, the base of a cumulus cloud.
A rapid flow of snow down a slope, such as a hill or mountain.
A landform created by deposition of sediment that is carried by a river as the flow leaves its mouth and enters slower-moving or standing water.
A long, narrow, deep inlet of the sea between high cliffs, as in Norway and Iceland, typically formed by submergence of a glaciated valley.
A spring characterized by intermittent discharge of water ejected turbulently and accompanied by steam.
A ring-shaped coral reef, island, or series of islets. An atoll surrounds a body of water called a lagoon.
A shrub or small tree that grows in coastal saline or brackish water. The term is also used for tropical coastal vegetation consisting of such species.
A mixed woodland-grassland ecosystem characterised by the trees being sufficiently widely spaced so that the canopy does not close.
A biome characterized by coniferous forests consisting mostly of pines, spruces, and larches.
A distinct ecosystem that is flooded by water, either permanently or seasonally, where oxygen-free processes prevail.
Traditionally defined as a seasonal reversing wind accompanied by corresponding changes in precipitation.
The action of surface processes (such as water flow or wind) that removes soil, rock, or dissolved material from one location on the Earth's crust, and then transports it to another location.
The process by which organic material becomes a fossil through the replacement of the original material and the filling of the original pore spaces with minerals.
The production and emission of light by a living organism.
A process used by plants, algae and certain bacteria to harness energy from sunlight and turn it into chemical energy.
A state of minimal activity and metabolic depression undergone by some animal species during winter.
The seasonal movement of animals from one region to another.
The use of any combination of materials, coloration, or illumination for concealment, either by making animals or objects hard to see, or by disguising them as something else.
Any type of a close and long-term biological interaction between two different biological organisms, be it mutualistic, commensalistic, or parasitic.
The transfer of pollen from a male part of a plant to a female part of a plant, later enabling fertilisation and the production of seeds.
Any preserved remains, impression, or trace of any once-living thing from a past geological age.
A transition area between two biological communities, where two communities meet and integrate.

sports.desc: Leading international sporting events featuring summer and winter sports competitions in which thousands of athletes from around the world participate in a variety of competitions.

An international association football competition contested by the senior men's national teams of the members of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body.

A team sport in which two teams, most commonly of five players each, opposing one another on a rectangular court, compete with the primary objective of shooting a basketball through the defender's hoop while preventing the opposing team from shooting through their own hoop.
A racket sport that can be played individually against a single opponent (singles) or between two teams of two players each (doubles).
The annual championship game of the National Football League (NFL).
The oldest tennis tournament in the world and is widely regarded as the most prestigious.
An annual men's multiple-stage bicycle race primarily held in France, while also occasionally passing through nearby countries.
The highest class of international auto racing for single-seater formula racing cars sanctioned by the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA).
A professional basketball league in North America. The league is composed of 30 teams and is one of the four major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada.
A professional baseball organization and the oldest of the major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada.
A professional ice hockey league in North America, currently comprising 32 teams: 25 in the United States and 7 in Canada.
A club-and-ball sport in which players use various clubs to hit balls into a series of holes on a course in as few strokes as possible.

sports.hint: Team sport with an oval ball
sports.desc: A close-contact team sport that originated in England in the first half of the 19th century.

A combat sport in which two people, usually wearing protective gloves and other protective equipment such as hand wraps and mouthguards, throw punches at each other for a predetermined amount of time in a boxing ring.
A long-distance foot race with a distance of 42.195 kilometres (26 miles 385 yards), usually run as a road race.
An endurance multisport race consisting of swimming, cycling, and running over various distances.
A team sport in which two teams of six players are separated by a net. Each team tries to score points by grounding a ball on the other team's court under organized rules.
A sport that includes physical exercises requiring balance, strength, flexibility, agility, coordination, and endurance.
An individual or team racing sport that requires the use of one's entire body to move through water.
A means of transport using skis to glide on snow. Variations of purpose include basic transport, a recreational activity, or a competitive winter sport.
A recreational and competitive activity that involves descending a snow-covered slope while standing on a snowboard attached to a rider's feet.
A surface water sport in which an individual, a surfer, uses a board to ride on the forward section, or face, of a moving wave of water, which usually carries the surfer towards the shore.
A recreational activity, an art form, an entertainment industry job, and a method of transportation.
An American mixed martial arts promotion company based in Las Vegas, Nevada. It is the largest MMA promotion in the world.
A form of competition using video games. Esports often takes the form of organized, multiplayer video game competitions, particularly between professional players, individually or as teams.
A contest featuring five events. The name is derived from Greek: combining the words pente (five) and athlon (competition).
A combined event in athletics consisting of ten track and field events.

sports.hint: Sport with a bow and arrow
sports.desc: The art, sport, practice, or skill of using a bow to shoot arrows.
A group of three related combat sports. The three disciplines in modern fencing are the foil, the épée, and the sabre.

anatomy.desc: The framework of the body, consisting of bones and other connective tissues, which protects and supports the body tissues and internal organs.

A muscular organ in most animals, which pumps blood through the blood vessels of the circulatory system. The pumped blood carries oxygen and nutrients to the body, while carrying metabolic waste such as carbon dioxide to the lungs.
An organ that serves as the center of the nervous system in all vertebrate and most invertebrate animals. It is located in the head, usually close to the sensory organs for senses such as vision.
A pair of spongy, air-filled organs located on either side of the chest (thorax). The trachea (windpipe) conducts inhaled air into the lungs through its tubular branches, called bronchi.
A large, meaty organ that sits on the right side of the belly. The liver's main job is to filter the blood coming from the digestive tract, before passing it to the rest of the body.

Two bean-shaped organs, each about the size of a fist. They are located just below the rib cage, one on each side of your spine. Healthy kidneys filter about a half cup of blood every minute, removing wastes and extra water to make urine.
A long, continuous tube running from the stomach to the anus. Most absorption of nutrients and water happen here. The intestines include the small intestine, large intestine, and rectum.
An organ in the upper far left part of the abdomen, to the left of the stomach. The spleen plays multiple supporting roles in the body. It acts as a filter for blood as part of the immune system.

An organ located in the abdomen. It plays an essential role in converting the food we eat into fuel for the body's cells. The pancreas has two main functions: an exocrine function that helps in digestion and an endocrine function that regulates blood sugar.
A small, pear-shaped organ on the right side of your abdomen, just beneath your liver. The gallbladder holds a digestive fluid called bile that's released into your small intestine.

A muscular sac in the pelvis, just above and behind the pubic bone. When empty, the bladder is about the size and shape of a pear. Urine is made in the kidneys and travels down two tubes called ureters to the bladder.

A soft tissue found in most animals. Muscle cells contain protein filaments of actin and myosin that slide past one another, producing a contraction that changes both the length and the shape of the cell.
The network of nerve cells and fibers that transmits nerve impulses between parts of the body.
The collection of glands that produce hormones that regulate metabolism, growth and development, tissue function, sexual function, reproduction, sleep, and mood, among other things.
The system that contains the heart and the blood vessels and moves blood throughout the body.
A biological system consisting of specific organs and structures used for gas exchange in animals and plants.
A group of organs working together to convert food into energy and basic nutrients to feed the entire body.
A complex network of cells and proteins that defends the body against infection.
The layer of usually soft, flexible outer tissue covering the body of a vertebrate animal, with three main functions: protection, regulation, and sensation.
Rigid organs that constitute part of the endoskeleton of vertebrates. They function to move, support and protect the various organs of the body, produce red and white blood cells and store minerals.
The connection made between bones in the body which link the skeletal system into a functional whole.
A flexible but inelastic cord of strong fibrous collagen tissue attaching a muscle to a bone.
The fibrous connective tissue that connects bones to other bones.

A resilient and smooth elastic tissue, a rubber-like padding that covers and protects the ends of long bones at the joints and nerves, and is a structural component of the rib cage, the ear, the nose, the bronchial tubes, the intervertebral discs, and many other body components.
Blood vessels that deliver oxygen-rich blood from the heart to the tissues of the body.
Blood vessels that carry blood towards the heart. Most veins carry deoxygenated blood from the tissues back to the heart.
Fine branching blood vessels that form a network between the arterioles and venules.
An electrically excitable cell that communicates with other cells via specialized connections called synapses.
A class of signaling molecules in multicellular organisms that are sent to distant organs by complex biological processes to regulate physiology and behavior.

chemistry.desc: A tabular display of the chemical elements, which are arranged by atomic number, electron configuration, and recurring chemical properties. The structure of the table shows periodic trends.
An electrically neutral group of two or more atoms held together by chemical bonds. Molecules are distinguished from ions by their lack of electrical charge.
A molecule or ion capable of donating a proton (a hydrogen ion H+), known as a Brønsted–Lowry acid, or, capable of forming a covalent bond with an electron pair, known as a Lewis acid.
A basic, ionic salt of an alkali metal or alkaline earth metal chemical element. An alkali can also be defined as a base that dissolves in water.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
The smallest unit of ordinary matter that forms a chemical element.
A pure substance consisting only of atoms that all have the same numbers of protons in their atomic nuclei.
A substance formed when two or more chemical elements are chemically bonded together.
An atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to the loss or gain of one or more electrons.
Variants of a particular chemical element which differ in neutron number, and consequently in nucleon number.
A lasting attraction between atoms, ions or molecules that enables the formation of chemical compounds.
A process that leads to the chemical transformation of one set of chemical substances to another.
A special type of homogeneous mixture composed of two or more substances.
A substance that dissolves a solute, resulting in a solution.
A substance dissolved in another substance, known as a solvent.
A logarithmic scale used to specify the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution.
A substance or material consisting of very large molecules, or macromolecules, composed of many repeating subunits.
A large class of chemical compounds in which one or more atoms of carbon are covalently linked to atoms of other elements, most commonly hydrogen, oxygen, or nitrogen.
The study of compounds that are not organic, which are compounds that do not contain a carbon-hydrogen bond.
The loss of electrons or an increase in oxidation state by a molecule, atom, or ion.
The gain of electrons or a decrease in oxidation state by a molecule, atom, or ion.
A property of a thermodynamic system, defined as the sum of the system's internal energy and the product of its pressure and volume.
A scientific concept as well as a measurable physical property that is most commonly associated with a state of disorder, randomness, or uncertainty.
The state in which both reactants and products are present in concentrations which have no further tendency to change with time.
A common laboratory method of quantitative chemical analysis to determine the concentration of an identified analyte.

chemistry.hint: Study of interaction between matter and radiation
chemistry.desc: The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation as a function of the wavelength or frequency of the radiation.

A laboratory technique for the separation of a mixture. The mixture is dissolved in a fluid called the mobile phase, which carries it through a structure holding another material called the stationary phase.
Any of the gaseous elements helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon, and radon, occupying Group 18 of the periodic table.
A group in the periodic table consisting of five or six chemically related elements: fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine, and astatine.
Any of the elements in Group 1 of the periodic table: lithium, sodium, potassium, rubidium, cesium, and francium.

landmarks.desc: A wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower.

A colossal neoclassical sculpture on Liberty Island in New York Harbor in New York City, in the United States. The copper statue, a gift from the people of France to the people of the United States, was designed by French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and its metal framework was built by Gustave Eiffel.

An oval amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy, just east of the Roman Forum. It is the largest ancient amphitheatre ever built, and is still the largest standing amphitheatre in the world today, despite its age.

An ivory-white marble mausoleum on the south bank of the Yamuna river in the Indian city of Agra. It was commissioned in 1632 by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan to house the tomb of his favourite wife, Mumtaz Mahal.

A 15th-century Inca citadel located in the Eastern Cordillera of southern Peru on a 2,430-meter (7,970 ft) mountain ridge. It is located in the Cusco Region, Urubamba Province, Machupicchu District, above the Sacred Valley.
A series of fortifications that were built across the historical northern borders of ancient Chinese states and Imperial China as protection against various nomadic groups from the Eurasian Steppe.

A complex of ancient monuments on the Giza Plateau, on the outskirts of Cairo, Egypt. It includes the three Great Pyramids, the Great Sphinx, several cemeteries, a workers' village and an industrial complex.
A prehistoric monument in Wiltshire, England, two miles west of Amesbury. It consists of a ring of standing stones, each around 13 feet high, seven feet wide, and weighing around 25 tons.

An ancient citadel located on a rocky outcrop above the city of Athens and contains the remains of several ancient buildings of great architectural and historic significance, the most famous being the Parthenon.
A temple complex in Cambodia and the largest religious monument in the world, on a site measuring 162.6 hectares.

An Art Deco statue of Jesus Christ in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, created by French sculptor Paul Landowski and built by Brazilian engineer Heitor da Silva Costa, in collaboration with French engineer Albert Caquot.
A historic and archaeological city in southern Jordan. Petra is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system.
A massive sculpture carved into Mount Rushmore in the Black Hills region of South Dakota. Completed in 1941 under the direction of Gutzon Borglum and his son, Lincoln Borglum.
A multi-venue performing arts centre at Sydney Harbour in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. It is one of the 20th century's most famous and distinctive buildings.

A skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. With a total height of 829.8 m and a roof height of 828 m, the Burj Khalifa has been the tallest structure and building in the world since its topping out in 2009.
A fortified complex in the center of Moscow, overlooking the Moskva River to the south, Saint Basil's Cathedral and Red Square to the east, and the Alexander Garden to the west.
A palace complex in central Beijing, China. It houses the Palace Museum, and was the former Chinese imperial palace from the Ming dynasty to the end of the Qing dynasty.
The campanile, or freestanding bell tower, of the cathedral of the Italian city of Pisa, known worldwide for its nearly four-degree lean, the result of an unstable foundation.
An 18th-century neoclassical monument in Berlin, built on the orders of Prussian king Frederick William II after the temporary restoration of order during the Batavian Revolution.
An American landmark and cultural icon overlooking Hollywood, Los Angeles, California. It is situated on Mount Lee, in the Hollywood Hills area of the Santa Monica Mountains.
A suspension bridge spanning the Golden Gate, the one-mile-wide strait connecting San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean.
A 19th-century Romanesque Revival palace on a rugged hill above the village of Hohenschwangau near Füssen in southwest Bavaria, Germany.
A large unfinished Roman Catholic minor basilica in the Eixample district of Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Designed by Spanish/Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí.
The world's largest art museum and a historic monument in Paris, France. A central landmark of the city, it is located on the Right Bank of the Seine in the city's 1st arrondissement.
The principal royal residence of France from 1682, under Louis XIV, until the start of the French Revolution in 1789, under Louis XVI.
The nickname for the Great Bell of the striking clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London; the name is frequently extended to refer to both the clock and the clock tower.
A historic castle on the north bank of the River Thames in central London. It was founded towards the end of 1066 as part of the Norman Conquest of England.
A palace and fortress complex located in Granada, Andalusia, Spain. It was originally constructed as a small fortress in AD 889 on the remains of Roman fortifications.

A Chilean island in the southeastern Pacific Ocean, at the southeasternmost point of the Polynesian Triangle in Oceania. Easter Island is most famous for its nearly 1,000 extant monumental statues, called moai.
A large pre-Columbian city built by the Maya people of the Terminal Classic period. The archaeological site is located in Tinúm Municipality, Yucatán State, Mexico.

inventions.desc: A telecommunications device that permits two or more users to conduct a conversation when they are too far apart to be heard directly. Alexander Graham Bell was the first to be granted a United States patent for a device that produced clearly intelligible replication of the human voice in 1876.

An electric light with a wire filament heated until it glows. The filament is enclosed in a glass bulb with a vacuum or inert gas to protect the filament from oxidation. Thomas Edison is widely credited with its invention.

A self-propelled motor vehicle, usually with four wheels, that does not run on rails, and is used for the transportation of people. Karl Benz is credited with inventing the first practical automobile.

A powered, fixed-wing aircraft that is propelled forward by thrust from a jet engine, propeller, or rocket engine. The Wright brothers, Orville and Wilbur, are credited with inventing and building the world's first successful airplane and making the first controlled, sustained flight on December 17, 1903.

A machine that can be instructed to carry out sequences of arithmetic or logical operations automatically via computer programming. Modern computers have the ability to follow generalized sets of operations, called programs.
A device for applying pressure to an inked surface resting upon a print medium, thereby transferring the ink. Johannes Gutenberg is credited with its invention around 1440.
A circular object that revolves on an axle and is fixed below a vehicle or other object to enable it to move easily over the ground. Invented in Mesopotamia around 3500 B.C.
An instrument used for navigation and orientation that shows direction relative to the geographic cardinal directions. Invented in ancient China.
A heat engine in which the combustion of a fuel occurs with an oxidizer in a combustion chamber that is an integral part of the working fluid flow circuit.
The process of removing heat from a low-temperature reservoir and transferring it to a high-temperature reservoir. The invention of the refrigerator revolutionized the food industry.

A group of antibiotics which include penicillin G, penicillin V, procaine penicillin, and benzathine penicillin, which are used to treat many different types of bacterial infections. Discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928.
The administration of a vaccine to help the immune system develop protection from a disease. The practice was pioneered by Edward Jenner in 1796.
The global system of interconnected computer networks that uses the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP) to communicate between networks and devices.

An information system where documents and other web resources are identified by Uniform Resource Locators, which may be interlinked by hyperlinks, and are accessible over the Internet. Invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
A satellite-based radionavigation system owned by the United States government and operated by the United States Space Force.
An optical instrument used to capture an image. The first permanent photograph was made in 1826 by Joseph Nicéphore Niépce.
The technology of signaling and communicating using radio waves. Guglielmo Marconi is credited as the inventor of radio.
A telecommunication medium used for transmitting moving images in monochrome, or in color, and in two or three dimensions and sound. The first electronic television was created by Philo Farnsworth.
A heat engine that performs mechanical work using steam as its working fluid. James Watt's improvements in the 18th century were fundamental to the changes brought by the Industrial Revolution.
A device consisting of one or more electrochemical cells with external connections for powering electrical devices. The first battery was invented by Alessandro Volta in 1800.
A farm tool for loosening or turning the soil before sowing seed or planting. The invention of the plow was a major advancement in agriculture.
A small object made of metal which is used as a fastener, as a peg to hang something, or sometimes as a decoration. The invention of the nail dates back to ancient Rome.
A thin sheet material produced by mechanically or chemically processing cellulose fibres derived from wood, rags, grasses or other vegetable sources in water. Invented in ancient China.
The earliest known chemical explosive. It consists of a mixture of sulfur, charcoal, and potassium nitrate. Invented in China during the 9th century.
A composite material composed of fine and coarse aggregate bonded together with a fluid cement that hardens over time. The ancient Romans were masters of using concrete.
A laboratory instrument used to examine objects that are too small to be seen by the naked eye. Invented in the late 16th century.

An optical instrument using lenses, curved mirrors, or a combination of both to observe distant objects, or various devices used to observe distant objects by their emission, absorption, or reflection of electromagnetic radiation. Invented in the early 17th century.
A form of electromagnetic radiation. X-rays are used in medicine for medical imaging. Discovered by Wilhelm Röntgen in 1895.

inventions.hint: Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation
inventions.desc: A device that emits light through a process of optical amplification based on the stimulated emission of electromagnetic radiation.
A semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power. It is the fundamental building block of modern electronic devices. Invented in 1947 at Bell Labs.
